In this problem, you will prove Lemma \ref{lemma:nimadd-rules}. For any integers a,b,c, prove that the following hold.
Additive inverse law: a \oplus a = 0,
Commutative law: a \oplus b = b \oplus a,
Associative law: (a \oplus b) \oplus c = a \oplus (b \oplus c).
Typically, the sum of two numbers n + m is not equal to their nim sum n \nimsum m. Under what conditions on n and m do we have the equality n+m = n \nimsum m? Explain.

This problem fills in some details about powers of 2.
Use induction to prove that
\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} 2^i = 2^{n} -1.
Use part (a) to prove that if k_1 > k_2 > \cdots k_r \geq 0 then
2^{k_1} > \sum_{i=2}^{r} 2^{k_i}.
Explain why there are always an odd number of winning moves from an \cN-position.

Prove that the \cN-positions and \cP-positions of Poker Nim are exactly the same as the \cN-positions and \cP-positions of Nim. In particular, be sure to explain how the winning player can prevent the game from going on forever.
Explain how two players of Poker Nim could work together to make the game last forever. What is the minimum number of beans that these players need to pull this off?
Let's add a third kind of move to Poker Nim: you can create a brand new nim heap on the board using beans in your personal cache. Does this change who wins the game?

Discover the secret to playing Northcott's Game.
Play Northcott's Game with one bLue checker and one Red checker on a single row. Who wins?
Play Northcott's Game using two rows. Who wins this game?
Prove that Northcott's Game is actually Nim in disguise (with bogus heaps). Be sure to explain what the heap sizes are, why they are bogus heaps, and how you can determine who the winner will be.
